title: MuLBSTA Score for Viral Pneumonia Mortality
description: Predicts 90-day mortality risk in patients with viral pneumonia using clinical and laboratory parameters to guide treatment decisions and resource allocation.

parameters.name: multilobar_infiltrates
parameters.description: Presence of multilobar infiltrates on chest imaging

ranges.interpretation: Score 0-5: Low risk of 90-day mortality (approximately 0-1.7%). Standard supportive care and monitoring appropriate.
Score 6-11: Moderate risk of 90-day mortality (approximately 7.3-26.7%). Consider enhanced monitoring, aggressive supportive care, and potential ICU admission.
Score 12: High risk of 90-day mortality (approximately 42.9%). Intensive monitoring, aggressive treatment, and ICU care strongly recommended.

references: Guo L, Wei D, Zhang X, Wu Y, Li Q, Zhou M, et al. Clinical Features Predicting Mortality Risk in Patients With Viral Pneumonia: The MuLBSTA Score. Front Microbiol. 2019;10:2752. doi: 10.3389/fmicb.2019.02752.

Chen N, Zhou M, Dong X, Qu J, Gong F, Han Y, et al. Epidemiological and clinical characteristics of 99 cases of 2019 novel coronavirus pneumonia in Wuhan, China: a descriptive study. Lancet. 2020;395(10223):507-513. doi: 10.1016/S0140-6736(20)30211-7.

Fan G, Tu C, Zhou F, Liu Z, Wang Y, Song B, et al. Comparison of severity scores for COVID-19 patients with pneumonia: a retrospective study. Eur Respir J. 2020;56(3):2002113. doi: 10.1183/13993003.02113-2020.
formula: MuLBSTA Score = Multilobar infiltrates (5 points) + Lymphopenia (4 points) + Bacterial coinfection (4 points) + Smoking history (3 points) + Hypertension (2 points) + Age ≥60 years (2 points). Maximum score: 20 points, but practical maximum observed is 12 points.
notes: Developed specifically for viral pneumonia mortality prediction
Validated in influenza and other viral pneumonia patients
Has been applied to COVID-19 pneumonia with good predictive value
MuLBSTA stands for: Multilobar infiltrates, Lymphopenia, Bacterial coinfection, Smoking, Hypertension, Age
Score ranges from 0-20 theoretically, but practical maximum is 12 points
Higher scores correlate with increased 90-day mortality risk
Helps guide treatment intensity and resource allocation
Useful for early identification of high-risk patients
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment
Multilobar infiltrates defined as involvement of ≥2 lobes on chest imaging
Bacterial coinfection determined by clinical, laboratory, or microbiologic evidence
Smoking history includes both current and former smokers
Hypertension based on medical history or current treatment
Age cutoff is 60 years for the elderly risk factor
External validation studies show good discriminative ability
